title: MS08-067 / Windows Server Service RCE
context: Remote code execution in the Windows Server service (path canonicalization).
notes: Exploited by Conficker; wormable and widely used against Windows 2003 / XP with many language-pack targets.

title: EternalBlue (SMBv1 remote code execution)
context: SMBv1 remote code execution vulnerability exploited by leaked NSA tooling.
notes: Used in WannaCry and NotPetya campaigns; patch released before public exploit release.

title: Heartbleed (OpenSSL heartbeat over-read)
context: OpenSSL heartbeat implementation allowed reading server memory, leaking keys and secrets.
notes: Wide impact on TLS-enabled services; required key rotation and OpenSSL updates.

title: Shellshock (Bash environment function parsing)
context: Bash parsing flaw allowing code execution via crafted environment variables.
notes: Affected many Unix-like systems where Bash was used; multiple follow-up fixes required.

title: Apache Struts Jakarta Multipart parser RCE
context: Crafted Content-Type (or related header) allowed command execution in Struts 2.
notes: Instrumental in the 2017 Equifax breach when an internet-facing instance went unpatched.

title: BlueKeep (RDP Remote Code Execution)
context: Critical RDP remote code execution in Remote Desktop Services with wormable potential.
notes: Microsoft issued patches and guidance; high concern for legacy, unpatched systems.

title: SMBGhost (SMBv3 compression RCE)
context: SMBv3 handling vulnerability (compression) allowing remote code execution on vulnerable hosts.
notes: Patch and mitigations published; noted for potential wormability.

title: Windows LNK Shortcut Parsing Vulnerability
context: Processing of specially crafted LNK shortcut files leading to arbitrary code execution when icons were rendered.
notes: Used by Stuxnet alongside other zero-days to propagate via USB into air-gapped industrial networks.

title: Internet Explorer Aurora Use-After-Free
context: Use-after-free in IE's peer factory objects allowed remote code execution via malicious websites.
notes: Exploited in Operation Aurora attacks against Google and other firms to install Hydraq backdoors.

title: Windows Print Spooler Stuxnet Propagation RCE
context: Shared printer spool directory permissions allowed remote code execution when malicious printer drivers were uploaded.
notes: One of the Stuxnet propagation vectors enabling code execution across network shares in industrial environments.

title: Windows Task Scheduler Stuxnet Privilege Escalation
context: Task Scheduler's handling of .JOB files allowed local privilege escalation to SYSTEM on Windows.
notes: Used by Stuxnet to maintain elevated privileges once initial footholds were established.

title: ZeroLogon (Netlogon Elevation of Privilege)
context: Cryptographic flaw in Netlogon allowing an attacker to impersonate machines and set empty domain passwords via Netlogon RPC.
notes: High severity; enables domain takeover if domain controllers are reachable and unpatched.

title: MS12-020 / RDP Use-After-Free (DoS, implied RCE attempts)
context: RDP use-after-free causing DoS; public discussion and Metasploit research explored potential RCE paths but public, reliable RCE was not documented.
notes: Popular Metasploit module due to community interest and research activity; primarily a DoS in public disclosures.

title: MS06-040 / NetpwPathCanonicalize Overflow
context: Server service path canonicalization overflow allowing remote code execution on older Windows versions.
notes: No official patch for NT4; useful against legacy systems where NT4 is still present.

title: MS03-026 / RPC DCOM Interface Overflow
context: RPC DCOM buffer overflow enabling remote code execution on older Windows systems.
notes: Used by Blaster and Nachi worms; historically the de-facto reliable exploit for many NT-era machines.

title: MS10-006 / SMB Client Infinite Loop (Windows 7 / Server 2008 R2)
context: SMB client bug that can cause an infinite loop / crash when a client connects to a malicious SMB server.
notes: Client-side DoS demonstrated against Windows 7 / Server 2008 R2; not an RCE.

title: Adobe Reader Embedded EXE (social engineering)
context: Technique embedding and executing a PE inside a PDF to achieve code execution when the PDF is opened.
notes: Used in social-engineering style attacks; popular meterpreter/embedded-PE module for Adobe Reader.

title: Apache mod_isapi <= 2.2.14 Dangling Pointer
context: Dangling pointer vulnerability in mod_isapi leading to DoS on Windows hosts running vulnerable Apache/mod_isapi.
notes: Windows-only impact; generally a DoS rather than RCE.

title: Java AtomicReferenceArray Type Violation
context: Type violation in Java's AtomicReferenceArray exploited as a cross-platform Java RCE affecting vulnerable Java runtimes.
notes: Public exploit demonstrated Meterpreter sessions on Windows, Linux, and macOS for affected Java versions.

title: Authenticated Windows Code Execution (PSExec-style utility use)
context: Post-authenticated remote execution via administrative services (utility module pattern rather than a single bug).
notes: PSExec and similar techniques allow remote command execution when valid credentials with sufficient privileges are available; common in post-exploitation and testing.

title: MS05-039 / Plug and Play Service Overflow
context: Plug and Play service overflow exploited to gain code execution on Windows 2000-era systems.
notes: Used by Zotob and other early worms; historically important for Windows 2000 exploitation.

title: Spectre Variant 1 (Bounds Check Bypass)
context: Speculative execution side channel where mispredicted bounds checks allow reading data across privilege boundaries.
notes: Required coordinated mitigations across operating systems, browsers, and microcode to reduce transient execution leakage.

title: Spectre Variant 2 (Branch Target Injection)
context: Indirect branch prediction poisoning enabling attacker-controlled speculative execution and data disclosure.
notes: Drove the deployment of retpolines, firmware updates, and broader discussions around CPU speculation hardening.

title: Meltdown (Rogue Data Cache Load)
context: Speculative execution flaw letting user-mode code read kernel memory via out-of-order execution side channels.
notes: Prompted kernel page table isolation (KPTI) rollouts and demonstrated the impact of hardware microarchitectural bugs.

title: Microsoft Office Equation Editor Stack Buffer Overflow
context: Legacy EQNEDT32 component contains stack overflow allowing crafted Office documents to execute arbitrary code.
notes: Heavily weaponized by crimeware and state actors; remained viable for years due to slow patch adoption.

title: Microsoft Word/WordPad RTF Remote Code Execution
context: Malformed RTF files trigger script execution via the Windows OLE2Link object when opened in Word or WordPad.
notes: Became a staple phishing attachment vector, loading malware with minimal user interaction.

title: Windows Common Controls MSCOMCTL.OCX Memory Corruption
context: ActiveX control memory corruption exploited through Office documents and other containers embedding MSCOMCTL.OCX.
notes: Long-lived client-side exploit used by espionage and financially motivated campaigns alike.

title: Microsoft Office OLE Packager Script Execution
context: Packager-enabled OLE object in documents allows remote template retrieval and arbitrary code execution.
notes: Popular downloader vector that bridged Office phishing documents to follow-on payloads.

title: Java SE HotSpot Type Confusion
context: Type confusion in HotSpot verifier allows malicious applets to escape the Java sandbox and run arbitrary code.
notes: Frequently bundled into exploit kits delivering ransomware and banking malware.

title: ProxyShell Microsoft Exchange Server RCE Chain
context: Client Access Service vulnerabilities combine to bypass authentication and execute code on internet-facing Exchange servers.
notes: Extensively exploited to drop web shells and ransomware across exposed enterprise email infrastructure.

title: Pulse Connect Secure Arbitrary File Read
context: Unauthenticated path traversal allows attackers to exfiltrate credentials and configuration files from VPN appliances.
notes: Led directly to network intrusions when threat actors harvested credentials and deployed follow-on malware.

title: Log4Shell Apache Log4j JNDI Remote Code Execution
context: User-controlled strings logged by vulnerable Log4j triggers JNDI lookups that load attacker-controlled classes.
notes: Global emergency affecting countless Java applications; exploitation observed within hours of disclosure.

title: VBScript Engine Use-After-Free
context: Use-after-free in VBScript when handling Class_Terminate allowing remote code execution via web pages or Office files.
notes: Also known as Double Kill; patched after widespread exploitation through Internet Explorer.

title: Microsoft Silverlight Remote Code Execution
context: Improper memory handling permits crafted Silverlight applications to execute arbitrary code in the user's context.
notes: Favored by exploit kits targeting browsers with the Silverlight plugin installed.

title: Citrix ADC / Gateway Directory Traversal to RCE
context: VPN endpoint directory traversal allows writing templates that execute commands on the appliance.
notes: Branded Shitrix; mass exploitation granted attackers footholds into corporate networks.

title: Microsoft Office Equation Editor Memory Corruption
context: Another flaw in the retired Equation Editor component enabling crafted documents to run code with user privileges.
notes: Follow-up to CVE-2017-11882, continuing abuse of EQNEDT32 in targeted phishing campaigns.

title: ProxyLogon Exchange Server SSRF
context: Server-side request forgery against Exchange's autodiscover endpoint allowing arbitrary HTTP requests and mailbox access.
notes: Kickstarted mass compromises in early 2021 when chained with post-authentication vulnerabilities.

title: Oracle WebLogic Deserialization Remote Code Execution
context: XMLDecoder deserialization of crafted XML triggers unauthenticated command execution over HTTP.
notes: Rapidly weaponized for cryptocurrency mining and ransomware deployment on exposed middleware.

title: Fortinet FortiOS SSL VPN Path Traversal
context: SSL VPN web portal allows unauthenticated file downloads, leaking credentials and session information.
notes: Widely harvested credential dumps fueled later intrusions and ransomware operations.

title: Atlassian Confluence OGNL Injection
context: Template injection via WebWork/OGNL enables unauthenticated attackers to run commands on Confluence servers.
notes: Aggressively exploited to deploy coin miners and web shells within days of disclosure.

title: MS14-068 Kerberos Privilege Escalation
context: Kerberos KDC validation flaw lets authenticated users forge ticket-granting tickets and escalate to domain admin.
notes: Highly prized for post-compromise privilege escalation in Windows domains before patches were broadly applied.

title: Kaminsky DNS Cache Poisoning
context: Predictable transaction IDs and source ports let attackers poison DNS caches with malicious records.
notes: Triggered coordinated global patching to introduce source port randomization across DNS software.

title: MS02-039 SQL Server Resolution Service Overflow (Slammer)
context: UDP 1434 resolution service buffer overflow enabling wormable remote code execution.
notes: Fueled the SQL Slammer worm that congested global networks within minutes in January 2003.

title: Adobe Flash Hacking Team Use-After-Free
context: After Hacking Team leak, a Stagefright-style use-after-free allowed Flash content to execute arbitrary code.
notes: Rapidly rolled into exploit kits prompting browsers to accelerate Flash deprecation timelines.

title: Exim Mail Transfer Agent Remote Command Execution
context: Malicious SNI in TLS negotiation triggers command injection when Exim routes mail.
notes: Enabled unauthenticated root access on widely deployed Unix mail servers when left unpatched.

title: Windows LSA Spoofing Vulnerability
context: LSA RPC interface can be coerced into authenticating to attacker-controlled hosts, enabling relay-style domain compromise.
notes: Mitigations tied to PetitPotam and AD CS abuse scenarios to harden enterprise identity services.

title: Follina Microsoft Support Diagnostic Tool RCE
context: Crafted Office documents invoke MSDT via ms-msdt URLs without macros, allowing command execution under user context.
notes: Enabled macro-less phishing chains; Microsoft issued guidance before a full patch was available.

title: PrintNightmare Windows Print Spooler RCE
context: Print Spooler improperly handles printer drivers, allowing remote code execution and local privilege escalation.
notes: Urgent patches and configuration changes were required after exploit code leaked ahead of patch maturity.

title: Accellion FTA SSRF and Command Execution
context: Server-side request forgery in legacy FTA appliance enables attackers to execute commands via crafted requests.
notes: Attackers exfiltrated sensitive data from organizations using the obsolete platform before patches or migrations.

title: MOVEit Transfer SQL Injection
context: SQL injection in MOVEit Transfer allows unauthenticated attackers to escalate privileges and execute code.
notes: Mass exploitation campaign by Cl0p ransomware group impacted hundreds of organizations.

title: Citrix Bleed NetScaler ADC/Gateway Information Disclosure
context: Memory handling flaw in HTTP/2 multiplexing leaks session tokens and authentication data to unauthenticated attackers.
notes: Attackers harvested tokens to bypass multifactor protections on critical remote access infrastructure.

title: Barracuda ESG Email Attachment Command Injection
context: Malicious TAR attachments trigger command injection in appliance scanning modules.
notes: State-aligned actors leveraged the flaw for persistent access, leading to emergency appliance replacement guidance.

title: XZ Utils Backdoor in liblzma
context: Supply-chain backdoor in test releases of xz/liblzma introduced malicious code affecting SSH authentication.
notes: Rapid discovery prevented widespread compromise but highlighted open-source maintainer trust risks.

title: mountd Export List Length Bypass
context: Overly long export lists in some mountd implementations allow unauthorized systems to mount NFS shares.
notes: Early example of misconfigured network services exposing Unix filesystems to the internet.
